messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.HashCodeBuilderTest.testReflectionObjectCycle()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
500 :     public void testReflectionObjectCycle() {
501 :         ReflectionTestCycleA a = new ReflectionTestCycleA();
502 :         ReflectionTestCycleB b = new ReflectionTestCycleB();
503 :         a.b = b;
504 :         b.a = a;
505 :         
506 :         // Used to caused:
507 :         // java.lang.StackOverflowError
508 :         // at java.lang.ClassLoader.getCallerClassLoader(Native Method)
509 :         // at java.lang.Class.getDeclaredFields(Class.java:992)
510 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.reflectionAppend(HashCodeBuilder.java:373)
511 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.reflectionHashCode(HashCodeBuilder.java:349)
512 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.reflectionHashCode(HashCodeBuilder.java:155)
513 :         // at
514 :         // org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilderTest$ReflectionTestCycleB.hashCode(HashCodeBuilderTest.java:53)
515 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.append(HashCodeBuilder.java:422)
516 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.reflectionAppend(HashCodeBuilder.java:383)
517 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.reflectionHashCode(HashCodeBuilder.java:349)
518 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.reflectionHashCode(HashCodeBuilder.java:155)
519 :         // at
520 :         // org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilderTest$ReflectionTestCycleA.hashCode(HashCodeBuilderTest.java:42)
521 :         // at org.apache.commons.lang.builder.HashCodeBuilder.append(HashCodeBuilder.java:422)
522 : 
523 :         a.hashCode();
524 :         assertNull(HashCodeBuilder.getRegistry()); // error occurred here
527 :     }
```

The passing test with the highest token similarity to the failing test looks like:

 ```532 :     public void testToHashCodeEqualsHashCode() {
533 :         HashCodeBuilder hcb = new HashCodeBuilder(17, 37).append(new Object()).append('a');
534 :         assertEquals("hashCode() is no longer returning the same value as toHashCode() - see LANG-520", 
535 :                      hcb.toHashCode(), hcb.hashCode());
536 :     }
```

It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Expected: <null> but was: []
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.HashCodeBuilderTest.testReflectionObjectCycle(HashCodeBuilderTest.java:524)
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.

The failing test belongs to the `HashCodeBuilder` and `IDKey` classes in the `org.apache.commons.lang3.builder` package. Next, I will check for the methods covered by failing tests in these classes. Let's start by checking the methods covered in `HashCodeBuilder`.

messages.name: get_failing_tests_covered_methods_for_class
messages.content: [".reflectionAppend(java.lang.Object, java.lang.Class<?>, org.apache.commons.lang3.builder.HashCodeBuilder, boolean, java.lang.String[])", ".reflectionHashCode(java.lang.Object)", ".Anonymous-08bb65e2-404a-4824-8df5-cce668e43b77.initialValue()", ".getRegistry()", ".isRegistered(java.lang.Object)", ".reflectionHashCode(int, int, T, boolean, java.lang.Class<? super T>, java.lang.String[])", ".register(java.lang.Object)", ".unregister(java.lang.Object)", ".append(java.lang.Object)", ".HashCodeBuilder(int, int)", ".toHashCode()"]

The `HashCodeBuilder` class has several methods covered by failing tests. The method `getRegistry()` is one of them, which is called in the failing test and is expected to return `null`. The failure indicates that it did not return `null` as expected.
The `IDKey` class has three methods covered by failing tests. The `hashCode()` method is one of them. Let's retrieve the code snippet for the `hashCode()` method in the `IDKey` class.

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
